official-title.#text:
To provide for greater regulation of high frequency
		  trading of commodities futures and options and greater protection for
		  derivatives traders and trading facilities, and for other
		  purposes.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

quote.#text:
Protection from Rogue Oil Traders Engaging in Computerized Trading
			 Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Short title

Requirements
			 applicable to high frequency traders of commodity futures and options

text.#text: The

header.#text:
In
			 general

Requirements
				applicable to high frequency traders

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has defined in regulations as high
				frequency trading, unless the person has registered with the

(in
				such form, in such manner, and providing such information as the

shall prescribe) as a high frequency trader, and the registration has not
				expired or been suspended or revoked.

text.#text:
It shall be unlawful for any person to
				engage in an activity that the

header.#text: Registration

text.#text: A registered high frequency trader shall—

header.#text:
Other
				requirements

text.#text:
test all computer
				programs and algorithms used by the trader in any high frequency trading
				activity and determine whether the programs and algorithms are functioning
				properly, in such manner and with such frequency as the

establish and document high frequency
				trading system safeguards reasonably designed to ensure the proper function of
				all programs and algorithms used by the high frequency trader including
				conditions and parameters relating to the automatic termination, pausing, or
				cancellation of the trader’s messaging or trading activity, maximum message and
				trade execution rates and order sizes, intra-day risk position limits, and
				market and trade monitoring systems that are appropriate for ensuring
				compliance with the system safeguards, including systems designed to monitor
				market volatility and the trader’s risk position on an intra-day basis;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
periodically, in a form and manner
				to be determined by the

text.#text:
shall not simultaneously purchase and sell
				through the same or different accounts the same commodity contract, agreement,
				or transaction, unless the simultaneous purchases and sales are of a de minimis
				quantity and are reported to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
semiannual reports on the high frequency trading activities of the
				trader during the period covered by the report, in such form, in such manner,
				and containing such information as the

may require, signed by the
				chief executive officer (or equivalent officer) of the trader; and

text.#text: submit to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
by rule or regulation that
				relate to—

text.#text:
conform with such business conduct
				standards as may be prescribed by the

fraud,
				manipulation, and other abusive or disruptive practices, and other practices
				that may affect market integrity involving high frequency traders (including
				high frequency trades that are offered but not entered into); and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may
				determine are appropriate in the public interest or otherwise in furtherance of
				the purposes of this Act, including information necessary to develop a
				classification scheme and public reports relating to high frequency traders and
				trading activity and sub-categories
				thereto.

text.#text: such other matters as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall prescribe final regulations defining the activities that shall
			 be considered to be high frequency trading for purposes of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 4u of the
			 Commodities Exchange Act

text.#text:
Within 9 months
			 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

header.#text:
Deadline for
			 issuance of rules defining high frequency trading

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding at the end the
			 following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 9 of the
			 Commodity Exchange Act

header.#text:
Fine for high
			 frequency trading violation required to be based on the duration of the
			 violation

text.#text:
The amount of a fine imposed under this Act with
				respect to a violation of a high frequency trading regulation shall be
				determined on the basis of the number of seconds, including fractions of
				seconds, during which the violation
				continued.

header.#text:
Criminal
			 penalties

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by
			 adding at the end the following:

header.#text:
Statute of
			 limitations

text.#text:
An action, suit or proceeding for the enforcement of
				any civil fine, penalty, or forfeiture, pecuniary or otherwise, shall not be
				entertained unless commenced within 10 years after the date when the claim
				first accrued if, within the same period, the offender or the property is found
				within the United States in order that proper service may be made
				thereon.

header.#text:
Statute of
				limitations

Effective
			 dates

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
			 take effect on the date that is 9 months after the date of the enactment of
			 this Act.
